content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Funny puzzle

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Another excellent ASCII puzzle from Lisa. I expect no less.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle with clear statement and usefull hint. It's a good idea to supply the hex value code of the letters. Of course it's not the hardest one in the easy category :-) but this puzzle is probably too long for a clash. If i watch your own solution in C# it's obvious that it's very hard to write 90 lines of code in less than 15 minutes !

Hi, don't you think this puzzle is close to this one ?
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/ascii-art

Questions for anyone:

(1)
Is there a way to use the block 
█ 
in output in Codingame?

(2)
What "Tag" would I use to say this puzzle lets you practice converting from one data type to another (hex to binary)

(1) You may want to refer to this discussion:
https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/how-to-make-coc-puzzle-with-unicode-characters/188910

There was this puzzle which was previously "fixed" after approval because Unicode characters were tested: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/7896116584ee929de04f6b58ca77b39f1a37

(2) I would say "base conversion" but somehow no such tag was used before.
The closest one I can think of is the puzzles "Number of letters in a number - Binary", "Bit count to limit" and "Trits (Balanced Ternary Computing)", which have all used the "Mathematics" tag.

Hi Remi -- Thanks for the comment.
I had proposed this as a Clash originally earlier, and as a comment on that, player "5DN1L" commented 
"...while the objective of this clash is the same as that of ASCII Art, the required solution is quite different. So, I don't think the similarity is that much."

And I'm agreeing with that :)

Much of the work of my puzzle is figuring out how to change a hex-value to a 8-by-8 bit array (am I saying that right?), which is not at all needed in the puzzle you reference.

Oh shucks… you’re making me blush 

Thank you !!
I've just changed the tag "Base conversion" to "Radix", which is already used by several other puzzles.
